verses.text: Now the sons of the prophets said to Elisha, 'See, the place where we live with you is too cramped for us.'
verses.comment: The 'sons of the prophets' refers to a company or group of prophetic disciples.

verses.text: 'Let us go to the Jordan, and each of us take a log from there, and let us make a place to live there.' And he answered, 'Go.'
verses.comment: The Jordan River area was wooded; logs were needed for building.

verses.text: Then one of them said, 'Please come with your servants.' And he replied, 'I will go.'
verses.comment: 'Servants' here refers to the prophetic disciples.

verses.text: So he went with them. And when they came to the Jordan, they began to cut down trees.
But as one was cutting down a tree, the iron ax head fell into the water. He cried out and said, 'Oh, my master! It was borrowed.'
verses.comment: Iron was valuable; borrowing a tool and losing it was a serious matter.

verses.text: Then the man of God said, 'Where did it fall?' And he showed him the place. Elisha cut off a stick, threw it there, and made the iron float.
verses.comment: Elisha performs a miracle by making iron float—against the laws of nature.

verses.text: He said, 'Pick it up.' So he reached out his hand and took it.
verses.comment: Simple conclusion to the miracle story.

verses.text: Once when the king of Aram was at war with Israel, he consulted with his officers, saying, 'At such and such a place will be my camp.'
verses.comment: Aram refers to the kingdom centered in Damascus, usually translated 'Syria.'

verses.text: But the man of God sent word to the king of Israel, 'Beware that you do not pass this place, for the Arameans are coming down there.'
verses.comment: 'Man of God' refers to Elisha.

verses.text: So the king of Israel sent to the place of which the man of God told him. He warned him again and again, so that he kept himself safe there.
verses.comment: The translation 'warned him again and again' reflects the ongoing action.

verses.text: The heart of the king of Aram was greatly troubled because of this. He called his servants and said to them, 'Will you not show me which of us is for the king of Israel?'
verses.comment: The king suspects a traitor in his camp.

verses.text: But one of his servants said, 'No, my lord king; Elisha, the prophet in Israel, tells the king of Israel the words you speak in your bedroom.'
verses.comment: Hyperbolic expression showing Elisha's prophetic knowledge.

verses.text: He said, 'Go and see where he is, so I can send and seize him.' They told him, 'He is in Dothan.'
verses.comment: Dothan is about 12 miles north of Samaria.

verses.text: So he sent there horses, chariots, and a strong army. They came by night and surrounded the city.
verses.comment: 'Great army' is translated literally.

verses.text: When the servant of the man of God rose early and went out, there was an army with horses and chariots all around the city. And the servant said, 'Alas, my master! What shall we do?'
verses.comment: 'Alas' expresses distress or fear.

verses.text: He answered, 'Do not be afraid, for those who are with us are more than those who are with them.'
verses.comment: A statement about God's unseen protection.

verses.text: Then Elisha prayed and said, 'LORD, please open his eyes that he may see.' The LORD opened the young man's eyes, and he saw—the mountain was full of horses and chariots of fire all around Elisha.
verses.comment: 'Chariots of fire' echoes Elijah's translation.

verses.text: When the Arameans came down to him, Elisha prayed to the LORD and said, 'Strike this people with blindness.' So he struck them with blindness, as Elisha had asked.
verses.comment: The word for 'blindness' may imply confusion.

verses.text: Elisha said to them, 'This is not the way, nor is this the city. Follow me, and I will bring you to the man you seek.' And he led them to Samaria.
verses.comment: 'Samaria' was the capital of Israel; leading the blinded army there was an act of subterfuge.

verses.text: As soon as they entered Samaria, Elisha said, 'LORD, open the eyes of these men, that they may see.' So the LORD opened their eyes, and they saw that they were in the middle of Samaria.
When the king of Israel saw them, he said to Elisha, 'My father, shall I strike them down? Shall I strike them down?'
verses.comment: 'My father' is a respectful title for the prophet.

verses.text: But he answered, 'You shall not strike them down. Would you strike down those you have taken captive with your sword and bow? Set food and water before them, that they may eat and drink and return to their master.'
verses.comment: Showing mercy as part of God's will; reflects ancient customs of hospitality.

verses.text: So he prepared a great feast for them. And when they had eaten and drunk, he sent them away, and they returned to their master. And the bands of Aram no longer came into the land of Israel.
verses.comment: 'Bands' means raiding parties; there is a break in hostilities.

verses.text: After this, Ben-hadad king of Aram gathered all his army and went up and besieged Samaria.
verses.comment: 'Ben-hadad' was a common royal title in Aram.

verses.text: There was a great famine in Samaria, and they besieged it until a donkey's head was sold for eighty pieces of silver, and a quarter of a kab of dove's dung for five pieces of silver.
verses.comment: 'Kab' is a measure, about 1 quart; dove's dung may refer to a type of seed or actual dung, both are signs of famine.

verses.text: As the king of Israel was passing by on the wall, a woman cried out to him, saying, 'Help, my lord the king!'
He said, 'If the LORD does not help you, how can I help you? From the threshing floor, or from the winepress?'
verses.comment: The king admits his powerlessness during the famine.

verses.text: Then the king said to her, 'What is your trouble?' She answered, 'This woman said to me, “Give your son, so that we may eat him today, and we will eat my son tomorrow.”'
verses.comment: Horrors of famine—the eating of children as foretold in the law.

verses.text: 'So we boiled my son and ate him. The next day I said to her, “Give your son, and we will eat him.” But she has hidden her son.'
verses.comment: A tragic and shocking account of desperation.

verses.text: When the king heard the woman’s words, he tore his clothes. Now as he was passing by on the wall, people saw that he wore sackcloth beneath, against his flesh.
verses.comment: Tearing one’s clothes and wearing sackcloth show mourning and repentance.

verses.text: He said, 'May God do so to me, and even more, if the head of Elisha the son of Shaphat remains on him today.'
verses.comment: A vow of punishment, expressing royal anger at Elisha.

verses.text: Now Elisha was sitting in his house, and the elders were sitting with him. The king sent a messenger ahead, but before the messenger arrived, Elisha said to the elders, 'Do you see how this son of a murderer has sent to take away my head? When the messenger comes, shut the door and hold it against him. Is not the sound of his master’s feet behind him?'
verses.comment: 'Son of a murderer' refers to Ahab's murderous house.

verses.text: While he was still speaking with them, the messenger came down to him and said, 'This disaster is from the LORD. Why should I wait for the LORD any longer?'
verses.comment: Despairing of God’s help, probably a quote from the king through his messenger.
